div.head: SUDAN GOVERNMENT RAILWAYS.
div.p: EXPRESS SERVICE FROM NOVEMBER 1ST, UNTIL FURTHER NOTICE.

‡Sleeping and Dining Cars. From Nov. 1st sleeping and dining cars on Egyptian State Railways are attached to ordinary trains from Cairo on Mon., Wed., and Sat. at 3 p.m. and from Luxor on Tues., Thurs. and Sun. at 5.30 p.m.- From 2nd Dec. Luxe trains with sleeping and dining. Cars will run on same days leaving Cairo and Luxor at 6.30 p.m. Early in January these trains will be run daily. Express between Shellal and Halfa carry mails and 1st class passaengers only, but 2nd class passengers may be accepted if accomadation is available. Express steamers do not stop at any stations on either up or down journeys between Shellal and Halfa. To insure accommodation official passengers must have warrants stamped "Accommodation Available" by Sudan Agent, Cairo, or Civil Secretary, Khartoum. A specially fitted barge with 1st and 2nd class accommodations for native ladies will be attached to these steamers. There will be a restaurant on these mail steamers.

div.head: Cyprus Government Railway.
div.p: The Limassol S.S. Co. steamers with good passenger accommodation run between Cyprus & Egypt as follows:—

Trains run alongside the steamers on the quay, and passengers can be conveyed to Famagusta, Nicosia, Morphou and intermediate stations. Good hotel accommodation for tourists is provided at Famagusta, at the Savoy Hotel (Mr. Najem Houry proprietor). Olympus Hotel, Mount Troodos, 6000 ft. above the sea. Magnificent Scenery. Perfect climate. Season May to end of October. For information apply to Mr. Najem Houry, Managing Director of Cyprus Hotel Co., Army Contractor, Limassol, Cyprus. There is a good carriage road from Kopia (on Railway) to Troodos. At Famagusta may be seen the fine old Latin Cathedral (now a mosque) begun in 1300 and finished in 1312, together with other ancient ruins and the Venetian fortifications, the finest in the world. Also the tower or palace, the scene of "Othello'' and of Ford's "Lover's Melancholy.'' The climate of Cyprus in the winter months is delightful and the Island will well repay a visit.
Information as to tickets, trains, etc., may be obtained of Messrs. Thomas Cook & Son, Egypt, or from the General Manager Railways, Famagusta. G. BERT DAY, General Manager. 29248—31-12-907

div.head: EGYPT AND U.S.A.
div.p: In his annual report concerning the commerce of Egypt, the American Consul-General, Mr. Iddings, again calls the attention of American exporters to the trade requirements of this country. He outlines opportunities that exist for increasing American trade, and offers suggestions that should prove of value to those seeking it.

"A decided increase of interest in Egyptian trade, as indicated by letters of inquiry received at this agency and consulate-general, has been shown by American manufacturers, which is most encouraging The conditions which American manufacturers must meet if they wish to sell their wares in Egypt have not changed since they were set forth in previous reports Credit must be given, add "cash payment with the order" must not be insisted on. The manufacturer who sells the goods must interest himself to see that delivery is as prompt as possible."

"Inquiries as to the possibility of establishing a direct steamship line between New York and Alexandria have brought forth the following observations from a shipping merchant and business map of Cairo, who was for a long time a leading manager of a successful line of British steamships."

"A direct Ainerican line of steamships between New York and Alexandria, stopping at Marseille or Genoa, arriving once in 10 days, might, succeed without a subsidy. It would take $15,000,000 to establish it. The big ships would run to Alexandria, carrying many passengers. Small steamers, to act as feeders for the big direct ships, should collect freight at all the principal eastern Mediterranean ports. They could make the round from Alexandria, touching at Port Said, Jaffa, Beirout, Mersine, Smyrna, Constantinople Athens and Patmos. If such a line is ever seriously projected, there is much to be advised in regard to the construction and management of its steamships. Room still exists in Egypt for an American bank which would transact business with the United States without the aid of Paris and London. The legal banking rate in Egypt is 19% but 12 % is easily made. There are no cities in the world where there are better conditious for lending money on good security than in in Cairo and Alexandria. Some of the Egyptian banks in Cairo would like to establish branches in New York, but their charters forbid. Certain French banks are not thus fettered, but French banking ways would hardly suit Americans so well as English methods. An American bank would naturally obtain the business of American tourists, who in 1906 came in larger number than ever before

div.head: Savoy Hotel.
div.p: The first small dance of the season at the Savoy Hotel will plece on Satarday, December 21st.

div.head: Seizure of Hasheesh.
div.p: The Coast Guard Administration effected a seizure of 78 kilos of hasheesh in the Port Said harbour on the 6th inst.

div.head: The Brindiel Mail
div.p: The mail from Enrope via Brindisi and Port Said (P. and 0.) will be distributed at the Alexandria Post Office at 9 o'clock this evening.

div.head: Egyptian Lignolite and Brick Co.
div.p: The offices of The Egyptian Lignolite and Brick Co. Litd. Cairo, lately at Rue El Maghraby, have been transferred to Rue El Manak, Zola Honse, facing the Banque of Salonica.

div.head: Western Oasis Railway.
div.p: The Western Oasis Railway passed the headquarters of the Corporation of Western Egypt Limited, in the Oasis of Khargeh on the 7th inst. and atthe present rate of progress should reach the terminus by the end of the year.

div.head: The Legisiative Council.
div.p: The members of the Legislative Council were unable at Saturday's meeting to come to a decision whether to admit reporters at their deliberations. After a stormy discussion the President left the hall and the meeting broke up.

div.head: The Belgian Colony.
div.p: At a meéting of the Belgian Colony which was held on Saturday at the National Hotel under the presidency of Baron de Gaiffier destroy it was decided to form a Union Belge for commercial and other purposes. The officers and committee were duly elected.

div.head: The Boutao Crime.
div.p: Zaccaria Markakis, the Greek who murdered his young wife a few days ago bas committed suicide at an hotel at Tautah. The police of Tantah having communicated with Cairo, the deceased wife's sister and a member of the secret police were sent to identify the body.

div.head: Theft in Cairo.
div.p: Mustapha Bey Moalster, resident in the Saida district of Cairo, notified the police yesterday morning that the sum of L.E. 80 had been stolen from his money box, and, suspicions pointing to some carriers whohad been working near the spot where the rifled box was kept, four of them have been arrested antl an enquiry opened.

div.head: The Hew Regime.
div.p: A correspondent writes:—One of the important changes which the new régime is responsible for will be the immediate reduction of the English Inspectorate force in the Ministry of Finance Certain of these Inspectors. are to be transferred to the Police, but it is possible that thé Government will not have room for all the men who are to be dispensed with in this Department.

div.head: Cairo Sotentifio Seolety.
div.p: A meeting will be held at the School of Medicine, Kasr el Ainy, at 4.30 p.m. on the 12th inst. The following papers will be read : "On the effects produced by stimulating certain parts of the brain in Lizards" by Dr. W.A. Wilsow and "The relationship of Growth to Temperatare" by Mr. W.L. Balls, There will be an exhibition of new form of apparatus for thie exact determination of temperatures of microscopic objsects.

div.head: Cairo Water.
div.p: The official reed on the Water: Commission is not yet issoed, butwwe are informed on good anthority that the new report differs but ittle from the previously expressed opinion of Dr. Bitter, and that like him the commission are of opinion that the dark colour of the water is not caused by any dangerous fungi, but is due to the presence in the wells of certain harmless water weeds. The full report is to presented to the Prime Minister on Wednesday.

div.head: Omdurman Market.
div.p: A considerable number of the Omdarman merchants seem to be dissatisfied with the conditions required by the Government for building the shops.in the new Market. The requirements.are such, it is alleged, that the small merchant who complies with them would be obliged to tie up the larger part of his capital in the building, which leaves him very little with which to carry on his business. They are requesting the Government to reconsider the matter and amend the conditions in such a manner as not to keep the lesser merchants and tradesmen out of the new market.

div.head: Lord Cromer's Book.
div.p: Messrs. MacMillan and Co. will be the publishers of Lord Cromier's new book, "Modern Egypt." In the preface Lord ,Cromier states that his object in writing this book is twofold. In the first place he wishes to put on record an sccurate narrative of some of the principal events.which have occurred in Egypt and in the Sudan. since 1876; and in the second place to explain the results which have accrued to Egypt from the British occupation of the country in 1882. The work will be in two octavo volames, and will contain two portraits and a map.

div.head: New Alexandria Paper.
div.p: In spite of considerable sums of money lost every year in this country, in the attempts to start daily papers, the passion for founding new organs appears to be on the increase, despite the iling acute financial crisis. Last week we announced the foundation of an Italian daily new at Alexandria, "La Patria," and in a few days time a French daily paper will make its appearance. It is to -e published every morning, and will be the first newspaper at Alexandria to be printed on Linotype machines. It is to be called "Les Nouvelles' and the editor will be Mr. Du. mani, who edited a paper of the same name, which after attaining considerable popularity, suddenly disappeared. It will be printed at the Inprimerie Mourea.

div.head:
THE MECCA PILGRIMAGE.
FACILITIES IN TRAINING.
FACILITIES IN TRAVELLING.
div.p: (Gazette's Special Service).

The Constantinople correspondent of the "Morning Post" states,that the Sultan, in order to afford greater facilities to the Mecca pilgrims, bas given orders for the construction of a new railway from Mecca to Arafat and for the completion of the line from Medina to Mecca, a distance of 280 miles, before the next pilgrimage.

div.head: THE CONTANTINOPLE CRISIS.
div.p: London, Wednesday.
The commercial crisis at Constantinople shows signs of improving since summer. Fifteen firms of more or less repute have failed.

div.head: LORD CROMER FUND.
div.p: The British Community are earneotly invited toattend a meeting of the "Lord Cromer Fund, to be held at the Britist: Clab, Alexandria, on Monday the 16th inst. at 4 p.m. All British subjects are cordially asked to come.

div.head:
PORTS AND LIGHTS
THE OFFICIALS SENTENCED.
div.p: The proceedings betore the Native Court yesterday began at 9.30 am.

The advocate Mustafa El Khadem stated in his defence that the Parquet had not proved that Spiro Bey or Safwat had received a bribe so neither of them were guilty of corruption: The most important witness for the prosecution was Mahmdnd Neghib, who was under Safwat's orders on the quay. He declared that Safwat asked him for £5 as a bribe, and he reported this to Sir, Massie Blomfield and then to the Deputy Director General, bat as no steps were taken he sent his accusation to the Finance Ministty, who sent down a delegate to enquire.

The chief of the Parquet said that in the beginning of 1907 the Finance Ministry found out the corruption in the Ports and Lights and this is due to the authority, given to this administration to appoint employées whom they choose fit for the posts as exceptional cases without regard to regalations, and this is the why the officinls such as Spiro Bey etc., began to follow the which has led to the present case.

The Finatice Ministry then sent a delegate to open an inquiry with Dixon Bey, who made strict investigations gnd concluded that the origin of corraption was from Spiro Bey and Attiah Eff. in whose bands are nearly all the admini- strative works, promotions and transfers etc. Then the chief of Parquet pointed out how the first witness paid a bribe to Attiah who is the assistant of Spiro Bey.

The chief of the Parquet is of opinion that the prisoner Attiah ought to havé sent a reply to the registered letter of Hafer, if he had not really received the sum of LE 54 from him ( Hafez ) therefore that Attiah has really received this sum as a bribe for himself and Spiro Bey (who is absent) and consequently both of them are guilty. Sitting adjourned to 4 p.m.
The Court reassembled subsequently and heard some more witnesses, after which the Coart pronounced the following sentences :— Socrates Spiro Bey,three years imprisonment and a fine of L.E. 54.
Attia Effendi George, one year's imprison-
ment and a fine of LE 54.
These two were charged with receiving bribes.
Mustapha Marad and Darvish Mustapha, found guilty of falsifying documents, were each sentenced toxine year's imprisonment and the former fined L.E. 50 and LE. 30 costs.
Capondan Safwat and the others were acquitted.
The Court rose at 8 pm.

div.head: SUPREME CONSULAR COURT.
div.p: The two appeals of the Bourse and Banking Company of Egypt Limited against the judgment of the British Consular Court at Alexatidria came ou for hearing this morning before the Supreme Consular Court, Mr. Devonshire represented the appellasts. and Mr. Reginald Silley, and Mr. Gooding the shareholder, who brought the actions in the lower court, Judgment was reserved in the first case The second case is still continuing.

Yesterday the Captain of S.S. "Baku Standard," and the third mate and chief engineer of the same steamer, arrived at Alexandria yesterday evening from Europe by the S.S. "Heltopolis" in order to give evidence at the forthvoming trial before the Supreme Court of the fireman, Thomas Cannon, who 1s charged with murder.

div.head: CASSA DI SCONTO.
div.p: The action brought by Emin Bey Army against the Cassa di Sconto e di Risparmio will be heard 'before the Mixed' Commercial Court, Alexandria, on Monday next, the 16th inst.

div.head:
EGYPTIAN CONSTRUCTIONS HEAD
EXTRAORINARY MEETING.
div.p: We have recently published a notice of an extraordinary general meeting in the Egyptian Constructions Limited, which is to be held at 4 p.m. on the 21st inst: in Cairo, The company was started in February, 1906, and is an Nangovich Bey, Chairman, Mr. Montagu Summers, Mr. Thomas McClure, Mr. Stanley Dorling and Mr. GL. Pezzi The capital was £100,000 in 100,000 shares of £1 each, with power to increase to £200,000 by. resolution of the Board. The shares have stood as high as 1 7/8 and 4 large number of Anglo-Egyptians have been induced to put their capital into the company. The reasons, for which the extraordinary meeting for the 2lat inst. has been convened appear to have aroused some criticism, as the following letters will show. We may mention that Mr. Thomas McClure who appends his signature to one the letters, retired from the board early this year.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE "EGYPTIAN GAZZETTE."
Sir,

A crisis bas arrived in the affairs of the Egyptian Constractious Limited and much, if not all, depends on the decision which the shareholders will take at the extraordinary general meeting to be held on Satarday week, the 21st inst. At the beginning of this year the company was in a most flourishing condition and had excellent prospects, During the months that have elapsed a great amount of work has been carried out and, presumably, paid for. Nevertheless the shareholders find that the present Board of Directors has thought fit to convene this meeting for the purpose of disposing of those branches of the basiness, which.are actually carrying on the work of the company. All shareholders ought therefore to insist on s strict investigation of the business carried ont during the present year, They also should look into the conditions, ander which the business has been éarried out, and the disposal of the large sums of money received. I am, Sir,
Truly yours
Tuomas McClure
Alexandria, 10th December.
Sir,

Referring to the notice convening an extraordipary general meeting of the Egyptian Constructions, Limited, for the reduction of capital, oce is amazed that any directors shonld place sach proposals before a presamably intelligent body of shareholders. Not only did they give us only a few months ago a most glowing account of the fature prospects of the associated businesses, but pointed out the undoubtedly aniqae position the company held in the building and engineering trades owing to the sequisition of two private concerns. Without a farther word of explanation the shareholders are now asked to authorise a sweeping reduction of capital and the resale (probably at an enormous loss) of the businesses which were going to do so much for the company. Surely, before submitting such proposals the board should have given some statement of account and the reasons for the step they propose? Do-they want to rush their proposals through without explanation or discussion? In the present deplorable position of the company the shareholders should be in possession of full details for their very careful consideration before being asked to arrive at any decision. We shareholders are pleased at the opportunity of meeting the board and enquiring as to the truth of the many anpleasant ramoors being circulated about the company and its management, and to the effect that even if the board's resolutions are carried, the company will be left without working capital. It is certainly esseotial that the shareholders should pull to- gether in this matter by attending the meeting in fall force and appointing some of their nomber to investigate the position, and after discussion with the directors report to the shareholders as to the best course to pursue.
Yours faithfally,
SHAREHOLDER.
Cairo, 10th December.

div.head:
OBITUARY.
MRS. JULIA T. RALLI.
div.p: We regret to announce the death of Mrs. Julia Theodore Ralli, a member of the wellknown Greek family, many of whom are established in England, who died at her residence at San Stefano, Ramleh, yesterday afternoon at 4 o'clook. The deceased was widow of the late M1. Theodore Ralli, formerly President of the Hellenic Community at Alexandria, the wmother of Messrs. Anthony and Constantin Ralli, of Alexandria, and mother-in-law of Mr. Ambroise Ralli, to whom we beg to offer our sympathies in their bereavement. The funeral will take place at 3 p.m. to-day from the Ramleh Railway Station and the cortege will proceed to the Greek Cathedral.

div.head:
MARSEILLES TO EGYPT.
A THREE DAY JOURNEY
ARRIVAL OF THE "HELIOPOLIS."
div.p: (From Travelling Correspondent.)

No more voyage could have been made than the trip from Marseilles to Egypt by the Egyptian Mail S.S. Co's "Heliopolis". It has had indeed been to us a City of the Sun, for from start to finish we have been entertained with a liberality which the most exacting must have heartily appreciated. We have had a splendid run, kept well up to time, and throughout the voyage lived in the lap of luxury. In fact everybody was most enthusiastic in their praise of the "Heliopolis," whose maiden voyage must be voted a complete success. The day before leaving Marseilles a lunch was given on board to the notabilities of the town and its suburbs. Some 150 guests sat down to table, among whom I noticed the Prefet of the Department du Rhone, the General Commanding the Corps d'Armee, the Governor of Marseilles, all the Consular Corps, with the exception of the German Consul, the it leading shipowners and merchants of the town, and many other well-known local people. Boghos Pasha Nubar took the chair and gave us a most interesting speech in which he explained how the company had come to be ed. The founders of the company had for the past few years the development of senger traffic across the seas and had especially attracted, a4 has all the world, by the marvellous Atlantic service which exists to-day. But why shoald the Atlantic have the monopoly ? And, moreover, fast steamers had been running across the Atlantic for several years now, whereas the Mediterranean service had continued its jog-trot speed of a comparatively few knots per hour The company was formed, its first two boats were built, and the maiden voyage was now being made by one of the vessels which would place Mediterranean steamer traffic on a level with the Atlantic.

We left Marseilles at 1.30 p.m. on Saturday but the first day's ron was rather unsatisfactory, owing, I am told, to bad stoking. Up to midday on Saturday we made 395 knots. following day's run, however, was 456 knots, and between midday Monday and midday yesterday we covered 458 knots, thus leaving us 89 knots to ras, and this we did in four hours, for it was at 4 p.m. that the engines were stopped just outside Alexandria harbour to await the pilot. In considering these runs it must be remembered that, owing to the change of time, Sunday to Monday midday was not 24 hours but 28b. 10 min. and Monday to Tuesday 23h. 26 min.

Before conclading this little account of our trip I should like to mention that many are the souvenirs which have been left behind io the form of appreciative letters, etc. among whom I would mention contributions by such wellknown persons as Mr. Maurice Barrts, of the Academie Francaise, Mr. Georges Kaiser, Mr. Paul Adam, Mr. Jules Haret, Mr. Pierre Baudin, Mr. J. Verdier, Mr. J MacRichard Mr. Jean d'Ardenne, Mr. Gustave Tery and Mr. Sidney Low, who has come ont to Egypt to write a book on the country. The following was his contribution :—

How fair, how faint, across the years, The City of the Sun appears, How oft she danced before our eyes, Beyond the buried centuries ! Superb in history's glowing pages, Home of the gods, the priests, the mages, The pictured stones bring back to us, The Vision of Heredotus !
A mocking vision, so we ssid, A vanished world !an Egypt dead ! Ah no ! She rises from the earth, Incarnate in a later birth, And we may see the sunrise kiss A greater Heliopolis.

But ancient fables, in our days, Fulfil themselves in wondrous ways, How of the fairy stories tell Of cities floating on the swell Of moving islands, drifting free, Across the heaving wastes of sea ! Well now the tale is true again ; The moving isle is on the main.

No thing of post's gossamer, But twelve good thousand tons of her ; Palace and town and house and street, With iron hungs, that breathe and beat, The City of the Sun, once more, Wings her swift way to Egypt's shore, And bears us through the Middle Sea, In Cleopatra's luxury ; Bears us from Northern fog and frost, To that enchanted summer cosst, Our Island of the Bleet she is, The great ship "Héliopolis."
S.S. Heliopolis, at Sea.
SIDNEY LOW.

I have also captured the attached anonymous suggestion to the company :—"Some disappointment has been caused among lady passengers by the fact that their cabins are not provided with curling-tongs. We underthat owing to a regrettable error on the part of a subordinate a very limited supply of these useful articles was shipped, and these are all required for the use of the band. We believe, however, that the Captain has kindly offered to place his own private set at the disposal of any lady who may have forgotten to bring her own own. Application should be addressed to the third officer, accompanied by a lock of the applicant's own hair, if she has any." Needless to say a speedy reply came to the effect that the third officer anxiously awaited applications.
I must add that we had the advantage of receiving the latest news from marconigram stations which were served up as an hors d'æuvre at the breakfast table.

Mr. Norman Hamilton, of the "Daily Express" and "Standard," who was a passenger by the "Heliopolis" sends us the following:-- Staring me in the face on a raw, foggy November day in the big wooden open space opposite Aldwych theatre, I saw the now famous picture of an Arab chieftain with his hand shading his eyes, gazing across a sapphire sen sparkling with an Eastern sun, on a magnificent steamer in the distance. It was this picture that drew me like a magnet from London, and visions of past journies to Pharaoh land and of lazily moving dahabeabs moving up the Nile whisked me for moment to Mena House and the Pyramids like the magic carpet. For twenty years I have heard the East "a-calling" but never with such an imperatively insistent tone, and November 30th found me at Plymouth aboard the new steamer "Heliopolis." Prepared as I was for a surprise, having heard much of the new Egyptian Steamship Co. and having travelled on over forty of the world's ocean caravanserai lines, the "Heliopolis" for luxury, taste, and comfort, was a surprise and pleasure.

Accustomed as one is to the splendour of the American lines,as an old Eastern "voyageur" it must be yielded that the travelling public owe a great debt of gratitude to this new line, chiefly on account firstly of its great speed of 20 knots, which brought us to Marseilles in 96 hours, in place of the usual 6 days, secondly, its brilliant café restaurant under the able command of Monsieur Gelardi (of Claridges), and thirdly a band of really excellent Italian musicians and what is more fine vocalists as well.

On Saturday November 30th the new line received its baptism of passengers and started on its maiden voyage under the command of Captain Holloway R.N.R. a thorough mariner, and gentleman, whose kindly unaffected manners made us one and all his friends. The absence of any but trifling hitches on the first voyage not merely of a brand new ship but belonging as she does to a brand new line, was remarkable and caused great interest in the future doings of this enterprising company.

To myself, a hardened traveller, the most pleasing feature, duo I believe to Mr. G. T. Symons the Managing Director and Capt. Creighton, to whom is very largely due the perfect "tout ensemble" and absence of jarring note, is the cutting adrift from the old British policy of catering for Britain only and right pleased was I to see the right note struck by the management at Marseilles by inviting at "déjeuner" the "elito" of Marseilles and even some distinguished Parisienne chiefs among whom was the Prefect himself. This function undoubtedly gave great pleasure and some surprise to our French friends and was a most tactful and astute move, for the "Heliopolis" and "Cairo" will be the guest of France which is their European terminus.

I must not forget the café, a new and enjoyable feature on this splendid ocean palace. Passengers can dine or lunch here and are allowed 1/6, 2/6 and 3/6 for breakfast, dejenner, and dinner respectively, can invite each other to little parties for dinner which with music added of a refined character form charming interludes on the voyage to Egypt. No wonder we saw joining us at Marseilles a number of French and other passengers, a compliment indeed to a British steamer, for they invariably travel by Pronoh and German steamers and rarely under the blue ensign.
The journey ended on Tuesday December 10th by a record trip from Marseilles of a little over three days.

The arrival of the "Heliopolis" yesterday afternoon attracted to the quay hundreds of people, some of whom waited a weary three hours and more to get aboard. The long time which it took to bring the vessel alongside the quay was doubtless due to the facts that the harbour is very congested, turbine steamers are practically unknown to our port, and, thirdly, it is, we believe, the largest vessel that has been brought alongside. The delay, therefore, should be pardoned ; indeed Bakhry Bey should be congratulated on the way in which he handled the mammoth liner. When the ship was moored chaos prevailed. Hundreds were waiting to get aboard, some of whom had to meet passengers but most of whom had come to see the ship, but orders were given that nobody was to be allowed aboard until the passengers were ashore. The crowd protested forcibly, a few succeeded in wriggling their way past the police, and finally the gangway was stormed and all came aboard. Never had such a ship been seen in Alexandria harbour before, so Alexandrians vied with each other in being the first aboard. The police's task was an im- possible one and we must congratulate them upon the way in which they conducted their work.

div.head: SUSAN GOLDFEILD.
div.p: The balance sheet us at June 30 last shows that the mining and general expenditure account for the year amounted to £21,875 or, after the deduction of transfer fees, &c., a net sum of £21,882. In addition, an outlay of £5, 177 on buildings, machinery, and plant, and rolling stock, and £787 on surface and mine works was incurred. The superintendent's report sets on in detail the work accomplished, and the results achieved during the twelve months. A gratifying featore in this connection is the fact that nearly 1,000ft, of sinking and driving in excess of that for the previous year is recorded, the figures to the 30th June, 1907, being 4,639 ft. as against 3,686ft, for the corresponding period to the 30th June, 1906.

div.head:
THE YEMEN SITUATION
PEACE COMMISSION FAILURE.
div.p: Aden. December 4.

The Mecca Commission has left Hodeida for Mecca, and upon its departure the last hope of effecting a friendly settlement with the rebels is generally believed to have gone. The Turkish Pashas, who have been for more than two months in Yemen, are still at Hodeida, and will probably stay for some time there, though it is doubtful whether they will be able to do any appreciable good. I have recently met one who accompanied the Mecca Commission, and he confirmed what I have written regarding it. A remarkable feature in the Imam's reply was the religious title of Commander of the Faithful, which he affixed to his name and to which strong exception was taken by the Commission. It is assumed that this will be the last Peace Commission of Yemen for some time now Such Commissions are merely a waste of public money. I have more than once asserted in your columns that the real object of the Imam is supremacy and that anything short of complete autonomy will not satisfy him. As regards the Yemen deputation which went to Copstantinople, it is stated that a meeting was held at Sana, under the presidency of General Faizi Pasha, which was attended by the said deputation and the citizens at Sana and others. At this meeting expressions of the good feelings and sympathy of the Sultan were conveyed to the people of Yemen and General Faizi Pasha made a speech exhorting tho people to be loyal to the Sultan.
The Sultan of Zanzibar has left for home.
(Reuter)

div.head:
SOUTH AFRICAN SITUATION.
REVOLT AT VORSPOED.

div.p: 500 native miners at Vorepoed have revolted and destroyed everything - destructible. They are advancing on Kropnstadt. All the available police have left Bloemfontein. (Reuter)
Martial law has been proclaimed in Northern Natal. (Reuter)
Dini Zulu with 50 followers, reached Nongo- ma and surrendered unconditionally. Dini Zulo's follower are coming, in rapidly but the chief Mankalmana and other headmen are awaiting events (Reuter)

div.head: THE FUTURE OUTLOOK.
div.p: VI.

As soon as the present feverish activity prevailing at Port Sudan comes to an end and all the Government buildings are erected, it is very probable that the town wilk, lose a large number of its civilian inbabitants and for some years to come will remain in a state of stagnancy awaiting the development of the Sudan. In. the town and its neighbourhood there is nothing to attract a resident population except the desire of making money speedily. The climate is extremely hot and damp during the greater part of the year, Beyond the town stretches a dreary plain with only mimosa thorns for vegetation. The horizon is bounded by the desolate. Hadendowa mountains ten miles away. There are no amusements in the evening. and the distractions. prevailing at Egyptian ports ate probibited by-a paternal Government. Sunstroke is very prevalent in the summer and the dainp climate of the Red Sea enfeebles the constitution of Europeans. Living is very expensive, Eggs cost P.T. 1 a piece and cabbages P.T. 5, meat is P.T. 5 per oke and it is not always possible to obtain Deef, as the Hadendowas refuse to sell, for these Arabs teckon their wealth by their cattle and do not regard.the possession of money as an estimate of wealth. There is not a single inducement to tempt the European to live in Port Sudan save money-making, and as soon as the Government. contracts run out and there is no further need for European labour, the population: will inevitably begin to dwin- dle. The ships will cesse to call there as soon as the large consignments of Government material from Europe are no longer forth- coming and then Port Sudan will enter on a period of inaction until the Sudan begins to develop.

div.head: COMPARISON WITH SUAKIM.
div.p: It was thonght by the enthusiastic supporters of the scheme that the new town would be able to successfully compete with Suakim, but the old Red Sea port of the Sadan will go on and prosper while Port Sudan is. still waiting. The great advantage of Suakim is that it has large and most fertile areas of country to the South, which is rapidly developing into the most important, cotton producing centre in the Sudan. Port Sudan on the othér hand has no fertile hinterland of any sort or kind The only export of consequence from Port Sudan is gum and and all that could be taken away in a single large steamer. At Suakim the cotton exports are. inoreasing enormously. During the cotton season from January to August last 44,655 cantars of unginned cotton, valued at L.E. 43,980, were exported and 13,871 cantars of ginned cotton, of the value of L.E. 41,545, making the total value ofthe cotton exports L.E.85,525, The Tokar cotton area is increasing and every year it is cultivated with more success.

div.head: THE KASSALA TRADE.
div.p: The Government consider that. if a line of railway was brought from Kassala to the Nile- Red Sea Line, all the Kassala trade will be brought to Port Sudan, But it mast be remem- bered that all the traders with Kassala reside in Saakim and they will do their utmost to bring dl that trade to Snakim. The Govern- ment do not appear to reilise the intensitey of the feeling, which binds the Suakimese to their old bome. Why should they be so foulish as to leave their native town for Port Sudan, whose prospects are, after all, somewhat visionary ss far as the immediate future is concerned? If the native trader were to leave Suakim he would lose all the value of his large comfortable house there, which would remain empty, in order to dwell in the wooden shanties of Port Sudan. Trade rontes are ever conservative and Suakim will long continue to flourish while Port Sudan is just managing to eke out a precarious existence.

div.head: THE FUTURE.
div.p:
When the six hundred metres of quays are ready and the Government: buildings are com- plete, the labourers will depart and Port Sudan will relapse into a semi-deserted state. The only export trade in sight is that of gum in transit from Khartoum, which is about six thousand tons 4 year. The rest of the exports are about from five to six thousand tons, making a total export of twelve thousand tons per annum. The money thet actually remains in Port Sadan from handling this transit trade is about L.E 1,500. The imports at the outside amount to thirty thousand tons, not including the Government imports. Of these imports only

a very small part remains in the town and the profit actually remaining from building these imports and the commision may be estimated at PT. 15 per ton or L.E. 3,000 per annum from this transit trade. There is a little local trade in timber and dhurra for the looal require- ments of a town of four thousand inhabitants, three thousand of whom are natives.

What then is to be the outlook for Port Sudan? We are of opinion that the only outlook in the immediate,future must be one of patient resignation, say tor the next ten years, antil the Sadan makes some substantial pro- gress. The vast irrigation-works necessary for the «development of the Sudan have not yet begun and they will take many years to complete. The country, depopulated by the excesses of the Dervishes, has to await the coming of new generations to fill up the voids made by their massacres. All this will take time and it is childish to expect any im- mediate results, But as soon as this develop- ment begins to bear fruit, the effect will be at once evident in Port Sadan, whose harbour will increast in importance with the growth of Sudanese exports. To expect that it is to at once spring intoexistence as a flourishing harbour is absard, especially in a cogntry sit- uated as the Sudan is, for its fatdre is necessarily bound up withthe devélopment of a very slowly moving country. But although Port Sadan has many years of stagnant expectation and of hope deferred betore it, thete is every reason to believe that it will ultimately justify its existence.

div.head: EGYPTIAN POLITICS.
div.p: THE COPTS AND NATIONALISTS.

All the efforts of the Moslem Nationalists to induce the Copts to join them in political agitation have »been fruitless, The Coptic point of view. is well expressed in "Al Watan", the Cairo Coptic organ, which makes the followingcomment on the Nationalistic leaders and their real aims :—

We have never doubted for a moment that personal ends and religions motives were at the bottom of everything, done or said by these journalists who are supposed to be the leaders of political parties in Egypt. Mustafa Kamel goes to.the extreme end and pushes forward as hard as be can, because, he can find no other means for living. Were he to as certain now that a show of moderation would increase his income or enhance his fame he would become as moderate aa you like to-morrow. So are Sheikh Ali and his supporters counselling moderation and denouncing the extreme party because it pays them better to do so now. When they find it in their parsonal interest to be wildly extreme in their criticism of the present regime they will not hesitate a moment in outatepping even the bounds of "Al-Lewa" in their frenzied denunciation. They have done this on many: an occasion and they are most willing to do so whenever they think it better for their pockets. In fact they bave no natural or real feelings except such as they expressed aften the Denshwaa incident and snoh as "Al- Lewa" has been always evincing in these years. Perhaps our readers will remember that we foresaw the right thing early this year when we explained that by mutual arrangement or by common inspiration our presen day moderates were to cool down and leave the honour of permanent heat in the boatile cam- paign against the British rule to "Al-Lewa"' for some time. We have now full evidence that our suspicions were well founded and that the moderation of these "comrades" is at the best untrue.

Take their attitude towards Christians in general and Copts in particular, as an example of their patriotism and you will find that re- ligious fanaticism is the suin-aod-essence of all their politics and all the doings of their dives. Both the extreme and the moderate leaders have been calling upon the Copts of late to join their parties and pretending: the most innocent desire to see Moslems and Copts united as Egyptians to defend the common in terests. The leader of the extreme wing re- cently hired certain nobedies among the Copts to say that they are his faithfal follow ers. He eve invented Coptic names for some of his fabricated letters on this swbject. Yet the slightest provocation of the old prejudice or of the dominating fanaticism will speedily unmask these patriots and make them let the cat out of the bag as they have done in ctwo cases of recent date.

One of the two cases above referred to was that of Salib Bey Claudios, a most capable and trasworty servant of the Postal Administration who was lately promoted to a high position. Salib Bey is almost without equal in his serious and straightforward performance of duties and in the wide range of his acquirements and experience. He has gained this belated recognition of his services by the inevitable right of seniority and the unrivalled record of his services. Yet because he happens to be a Christian and a Copt his promotion was bitterly criticised in "Al-Lewa" and "Al-Moayad", both editors well knowing that Salib Bey was far soperior in all the requirements of his new post to any of the friends they would bave apoointed in his place.

The second case refers to the omdeh of Deirout, a village in Upper Egypt. That dignitary was some days ago relieved of his duties and a notable Copt eslected to fill his piece, Of course, the new omdel was not selected on aceount of his religion, for s Copt ie likely to lose rather than gain on that account nowadays. But ovr moderate and sincere friend "Al Moayed" could not hide his great disappoint- ment although the ease was hardly worthy of his great seal. He poured his venom unreser- vedly in critizing the appointment of a Christian omdeh end threw the mask of mo- deration to the . He has only shown his real metal this time and proved once again to all and sundry that toleration and moderation mean absolutely nothing to him. Like his rival of "Al Lewa," he is a dangerous agitator and a fanatic of the species. And we profoundly regret to say, the principles and purposes of these rivals are shared by millions.

div.head: EGYPT'S TRADE.
div.p: RRADY MADE CHOTHING.

The following statistics déaling with the im- sports of ready made clothing into Egypt during the past five years clearly demonstrate that the trade ieateadily increasing in volume year by year, and that Great Britain has only a very insignificant share of the market, despite the fact that she ranks third on the list of competing countries. It will aise be observed that whilet Austria does 65% of the trade, her nearest rival (France) is only credited with 16.7%.
Imports of ready made clothing into Egypt in L.E. for the years 1902, 1903, 1904, 1905, and 1906 .

As a matter of interest we may mention that in 1897 the total imports were, L.E. 129,000, whereas for the first nine months of the present year the figures were L.E. 279,491. These latter returns, by the way, show an in- crease Of L.E. 54.000 over the same period in 1906, so we are still on the upward movement. For Austria to have almost a monopoly of the Egyptian ready made clothing trade, it is obvious that there must be gome exceptional feature in her favour. As far-as we can gather, such factor lies not, as one might. expect, in having large up-to-date factories with all the latest machinery, put rather in her very cheap labour.

Briefly but, the system appears to be for the goods to be cut out in the factory and then given to contractors (or, as they are termed, master tailors) for completion. These men in torn-either ran small workshops in which ap- prentice labour is mainly employed, or they give the sewing ont to the peasants-in: the vil- lages, especially during the winter months The rules—which are upheld by the State— of the Tailors' Guilds re apprentices greatly assist the above mentioned master tailors in turning out the goods with the least possible expense. It appears that before a man can commence in business as a tailor on his own account, he must have served at least four years as an apprentice (during which he receives merely his board and ledging) and about sight years as an improver at a very small wage. It is no exaggeration to say that a large amount of the work on ready made clothing is done by apprentices and improvers.

Another feature in favour of Austria is the fact that the trade in Egypt is more or less in the hands of three or four big firms, which have houses in Vienna and so import direct. They have their own branches in the larger Egyptian towns, and we understand, some of them are also interested in the smaller clothing shops in the villages. The combination is so strong that, although both England and Germany have at- tempted to get a footirg the efforts they have made in this direction have so far been unsuc cessful.

It must also be remembered that, for the last 40 or 50 years Austria has been in the Egyptian clothing trade and she, therefore, thoroughly understands the-reqairements of the market. Her Government, too, encourages the industry as far as possible by waiving all import-duties on materials. brought into the country and afterwards exported in the form of clothing. The main centre for the trade in, Austria is Vienna with some 3% villages in the neighbour: hood After the goods are finished they are packed for export ip strong: wooden cases, each some 1.20 metres (47 inghes) long by 1 metre (89 inches) high, and costing about 5/6. The cases (which are sometimes lined with water- proof paper) usuglly contain clothes to the value of abont L.E. 100. The freight and in- suranos from Vienna to Alexandria, may be reckoned at something like 2% or 3% of the cost, ahd a further 10% to 11% must be added for quay duties, landing charges, customs and clearing expenses, and cartage, to shop or warehouse.
(British Bulletin Chamber of Commerce)

div.head: ARMY AND NAVY.
div.p: The croiser "Diana," Captain H.S. Grant, which has taken up the duties of senior naval officer's ship on. the Egyptian coasts, has put in one half of ber two year commission. The Diana's new commission was probably the cause of her failing off in gunnery this year Last year she was third in the return of the Méditerranean Fleet, but this year she will not occupy so high a place according to a semi- official statement.

Lieutenant F. Carne Rasch, the senior sub. of the 6th Dragoon Guards, Mhow, who has been selected for service with the Egyptian Army, entered the Essex Regiment, in 1901, and transferred from the Pompadoers to the Carabiniers in September, 1903. Curiously his father, Sir Frederick Carne Rasch, Bart, M P., served in the Pompadours and in the Carabi niera. Mr. Rasch went through the Transvaal operations of 1901-02 with the Exsex Regiment's 1st Battalion (Queen's medal with five clasps)

div.head: ALL-RED ROUTE TO KHARTOUM.
div.p: The new route to Khartoum has evoked considerable interest in England and is being noticed by the London press, as the following extract from "The Globe" will show:-- The inauguration of a mail steamship service between Egypt and the Sudan, through the Red Sea, implies more than a new route to Khartoum, important as this is of itself. The line started by the Khedivial Mail Com pany, in agreement jointly with the Egyptian Government and the Sudan Administration, may, in fact, be regarded as resolve to prevent the Italianining of the Red Sea Coast and its trade. There was some fear of this when negotiations began a year ago between the Italian Government and the Rubattino Company of Conor for a monthly mail service between Italy, Northern Egypt, and the Red Sea porta right down the coast from Suez to Djibouti.

The scheme, however, encountered lively opposition from the Italian colony of Erythrea, whose sense of dignity and of material welfare was injured by the proposal from Rome and Genoa that the mail steamers should serve intermediate ports. For a time it was thought that the representations of the colony would I prevail, but the Italian Government has evidently refused to take this parochial view of Italian commerce, and it is now announced that the 1 first mail steamer from Genoa, Naples, and Messina will sail from Suez on December 8, touching at Port Sudan, anong other intermediate places. It was clearly incumbent to preserve British and Anglo Egyptian interests along the African cost especially; these interests, and the development of trade dependent on them, are assured by the weekly mail service of the two 16 knot steamers, "Prince Abbas" and "Al Kahirs."

The journey between Khartoum, and the Red Sea takes twenty hours, and the combined services the result in a saving of twenty-four hours over the fastest time by train along the Nile Valley, while having the political advantage of being an all British route. This is further more secured in the Mediterranean by the P. and 0. Brindisi service, or by the new British turbine line between Marseilles and Alexandria. By either way Khartoum is now brought within nine days distance of London. There is another important aspect of the case. The Nile Red Sea railway in bow brought for almost the first time into really Imperial use.

Retained accumulations within the bowels are partly resbaorbed into the gyeters, producing sometimes rheuma- tism, sometimes kidney trouble.
The blood being surcharged with acids, which ordinarily find their esape through the bowels when they are regular, rheumatism is the result.
Acid blood forms eryatals, which ac- cumulate about the ligaments, carti-
lages and sometimes the bones in the joints.

Such morbid accumalations of blood throw extry work upon the kidneys. The kidneys being unable to perform the unusual labor of exereting these poisona, ofton give way and kidney trouble is the result.
Permanent relief cannot be resnona- bly expected excaps by correcting the constipation.
Regular bowels are a great safe- guard to health. Peruna and Manalin are unexcelled the world over for chronic diseases affecting the bowels and kidneys.

Inntile d'ajouter que la tendance est lourde, On a vaguement l'impression que si les affaires chément, c'est sans doute un peu que les ven- deurs se tiennent sur la réserve, mais surtout que les acheteurs ont totalement disparu de la seéne.

Dans le groupe des titres secondaires, la Salt and Soda perd encore 6 pence a 14/3, la Delta Land 1/32 4 1-1/4, la Port Said Salt 3 pence A 12/3 et les Ritz Hotels 1/32 & 9/32. Tandis.que les valeors ci-dessus ont fiéchi sous le poids des offres, les suivantes, deman- dées su contraire, ont bénéficié d'une reprise. C'est ainsi que la Ramleh poursuit sa marche ascensionnelle de 4 7/16 & 4 1/2, a cause de V'actroissement de ses recettes ; l'Alexandria "Water se relgve aussi de 1 8/4 10 7/8. LA boukir avange également de 28/6 4 28/9.
Lase fea les fluctuations de la matinée. Les autres cours sont inchangés et pour la plapart nominaux.

Lundi prochain, 16 courant, aura lieu la vente aux enchtres publiques de 17 Obliga- tions nouvelles et 2 anciennes Crédit Foncier Egyptien, dont le prix est soutena & l'approche da tirage qui aura lieu ce jour: la, le 15 tonibant un dimanche.

div.head: LETTERS TO THE EDITOR.
div.p: We do not hold ourselves responsible for the opinions ex- presseed by our correspondents, but we wish, in spirit of fair play to all, to permit—within certainneceasary limits— free discussion.

div.head: COOK'S NILE TRIPS.
div.p: To the Editor of the "Egyptian Gazette"

Sir,—Having just returned to Cairo from a holiday trip up the Nile on Messrs T. Cook and Son's S.S. "Rameses" I cannot resist the temptation to write a few words in honest praise of the excellent arrangements which were made by that firm for our comfort both on board and on the river banks; hoping that you will be able to find space for my letter in your valuable paper, as I believe a short record of the considerate treatment we all receiyed from Cook's employés will be of general interest and especially 80 to those tourists who contemplate making the Nile trip this season.

The antiquities and scenery are continually being admired and written about, and why should we overlook the merits of the agency which enables us to travel in luxoriant ease from the farthest corner of the globe to see these works of nature and man, which otherwise we should never visit.

The advantages to be derived from travel- ling c/o. Cooks are well known, but it was certainly an eye-opener to me to observe the facilities which were so readily scoorded to our "party at every turn: No single hitch occurred daring the entire three weeks and the brilliant manner in which not unfrequent difficulties Cook and Son but it is literally impossible to withhold applause of true merit, and even the most critical traveller and epicure cwho has made the voyage to Assouan by one of their tourist steamers cannét help realising to, its fall extent the trath of the saying that "Cook is the King of Egypt".
Yours faithfully
A Passenger.

div.head: COMPANIES IN EGYPT
div.p: Sir,-- I quite agree with both "Lex" and "Vigilant" as to the urgent necessity of amending the English Companies Acts, so as to ensure the power of rendering effective its penal clauses. But they seem to have lost sight of a still greater peril and that is the unlimited power of voting given to large shareholders. One often reads of the apathy of shareholders in defending their interests. But what encouragement is there to a shareholder to act when be knows that one or two big shareholders can, and often do, if it suits them, overide the interests of numerous small holders of shares.

Of course, the shareholders' consent is necessary to any expenditure involving an increase of capital; but, there again, for the reason I have given, they would be baulked, if they presumed to oppose such a measure.

It may be objected that any limitation of voting power could be circumvented by a big holder splitting up his shares. Truly ; but this would be, morally speaking, a fraud and an evasion of the spirit of the Law; it should, consequently, entail the confiscation of such shares.
Yours truly,

div.head: A REVIEW OF A GREAT INDUSTRY (1742- 1907.)
div.p: Sheffield is probably the principal city in the world sg regards silver-plated work ; in fact, something like 100 tons of silver plate are produced there every year.

The processs of Sheffield plating, which has been renowned for a century and a half on account gf ite darability, was originally discovered throagh an accident by Thomas Bolsover about the year 1742, the component parts being copper and silver, but as is eee case.with the originators of a great idea, he did not realise the momertoos importance of lis discovery and it was reserved for a Mr. Hancock to utilise the principle, and show the great advantages to which copper, plated in this few method, could be applied. He atilised it forthe working of sack kinds of domestic ware and table decorations which ap to that period had been exclasively made in silver, viz :—tea urns, ton sets, epernes, salvers, spoons, forks, &e. The execellency of the manafactore is proven by the fact that many pieces of plate made between the year 1742 and 1762 are still in existence, showing practically little signs of usage. Originally the copper was plated on one side only; but in later years, meats were found to enable the plater tocoat the copper in both sides, and such perfection did this art of Sheffield plating sttain, tht it was celebrated throaghout the known world Previous to 1784 it was illegal to stamp any sign or letters apon an article of silver plate under a penalty of £100 but owing to inferior articles comipg on the market, it beeame necessary for high-class makers to protest themselves sod their goods stamped withs significant omrk under which their initials were invariably placed. For ins tance, at the botten of a miver might be stamped a Lion, with the initials "A.B." beneath, probably representing strength, and made by Albert Brown ; so all goods of Albert Brown's manufacture would be thes stamped. This, of urea, was @ primitive form of advertining. The process of maenfactare was slow, neater ally expensive, and consequently there arose a demand for a more expeditions form of production, and, as necessity brings invention, ao after period of 100 years, namely, about 1845, came the introduction of electro plating, which instantly revolutionined the system ot manufacturing Sheffield pine; for whilst in the old process the platér-produced the feet, handles, &e at a great cost of time out of solid sheets of silver, supported by scifer, and fastened so that silver was onlt to view and wear, it the new system, the article was placed in a bath, the silver deposited by au electrical process, and the manual laboor thus saved, prodaced the desired result. Im- mediately, the trade advanced by leaps snd bounds ; factories of every description sprang up, giving employment to thousands of per- sons, another great industry was added to the long role owning discovery to the creative genius of the Anglo Saxon race, Naturally there were at once, good bad, and indifferent mandfacturers and the necessity again arose for these whe desired to be knows ae The producers af the highest class of goods, to stamp their mark open the articles they produced.

One of the leading firme whe ere now manu- factoring electro plate at Sheffield, is :—- The Association of Diamond Merchants, Jewellers, and Silversmiths, Limited, whose London ad-- dress is Trafalgar Square, and who have always prodaced the highest ideals in elegance of desing, heaviest deposit of silver, and highest quality and finish ; on this account they are therefore justly celebrated throughout the world, and to distizigaish their goods from all other wakers, they plsce upon each article their Registered Mark "A.D M. Sheffield Al" which is s gagrantee that the article is of the highest quality. A spoott or fork stamped "A D M. Sheffield Al" therefore, is guaranteed to wear for.30 years, and at the same time, the cost is only half that of solid: silver, and wears equally as well. Doubtless the majority of the readers of this paper are already well acquainted with the world-wide reputation of this firm, bat should they be desirous of purchasing from a local tradesman or ordering through a ship per, any articles of "Sheffield" Plate it ix abso- lutely negessary to insist that the article bears the Registered Stamp. Imitation is the sin cerest form of flattery, and it is a very lucrative business to copy an article of the highest quality in a cheaper plate, and charging the price of the former.

The Association of Diamond Merchants, Jewellers, and Silversmiths, Limited, publish descriptive catalogue with illustrations and prices of their productions in "Sheffield" Plate, which they will forward free to anyone upon application.
